unnormalised: Planning a trip via Indian Railways can be quite an adventure, right? Especially when you’re staring at a WL ticket hoping it’ll confirm. It's like a rite of passage for any desi traveller. The whole process, from booking tickets on IRCTC to navigating crowded platforms, can seem a bit daunting at first. But trust me, once you get the hang of it, it's an experience like no other. Think of the scenic routes, the chai breaks at random stations, and the chance to meet all sorts of interesting people.

unnormalised: One of the first hurdles is figuring out the ticket booking system. You’ll likely be using the IRCTC website or app, which, let's be honest, can be a tad slow sometimes. Booking opens at 10:00 AM sharp for AC classes and 11:00 AM for sleeper class tickets, so be ready with your details. Make sure you have your Aadhaar linked too, it sometimes makes things easier. Keep an eye out for different train types like Rajdhani, Shatabdi, and Duronto - they offer varying levels of comfort and speed. And definitely check the PNR status after booking; knowing if you're RAC or confirmed is crucial.

And definitely check the P-N-R status after booking; knowing if you're R-A-C or confirmed is crucial.

unnormalised: Now, let's talk about the journey itself. The sheer scale of the Indian Railways network is mind-boggling. You can travel from Kanyakumari to Kashmir, all on a single railway line! Remember to pack some snacks and water, though you can usually find vendors selling food and drinks on the train. Also, download some movies or shows beforehand, as the internet connectivity can be patchy in many areas. Power banks are a lifesaver too; you don’t want your phone dying halfway through a 24-hour journey. I usually try to book 3A or 2A class; it makes the long journey a bit more bearable.

unnormalised: Once you reach your destination, getting around can be another challenge. If you're arriving at a major station like Mumbai CST or New Delhi, you'll find prepaid taxi services and auto-rickshaws outside. Uber and Ola are also readily available in most cities. But be prepared to haggle a bit, especially with the auto-rickshaw drivers. And remember to keep your belongings safe, especially in crowded areas.
